South Carolina just held a successful primary with no excuse absentee voting, meaning any registered voter can request a ballot by mail for any reason, and in-person voting at the polls. (4/5)
Absentee ballots, however, are requested by registered voters who wish to vote but are unable to make it to the polls on Election Day, such as members of the military and senior citizens. (3/5)

with no way to verify the ballot was even filled out by the right person. This would endanger the integrity and security of our elections. This is why elections conducted entirely by mail pose serious risks. (2/5)

As much as the media and the Left claim otherwise, there is a big difference between absentee voting and universal mail-in voting. Universal vote by mail would send ballots to mailboxes of voters who do not want them, who moved, or are potentially deceased, (1/5)

2.  Increasing either the special minimum benefit for low-income beneficiaries or for all beneficiaries would decrease the risk of economic insecurity associated with early retirement, making exiting the labor force a more viable option.

To strengthen #SocialSecurity, policymakers could do the following:  

1. Lifting or removing the cap on taxable earnings for #SocialSecurity could further strengthen the program by ensuring the program has adequate funding into the future.

Women and people of color across all three groups—retirees, near retirees and older workers—have a particularly tough time when it comes to retirement as a result of age discrimination and other economic inequities.

#COVID19 has made a bad situation worse—particularly for older workers. Staying in the workforce is especially dangerous and leaving the workforce is dangerous as well because the economic recession makes finding a new job and planning for retirement even more difficult.

In addition to the fact that employers have slowly shifted the burden of retirement back onto employees, the limit on taxable earnings for #SocialSecurity and a benefits formula that doesn’t provide as much as it should, have also weakened the American Retirement system.
The “three-legged stool” of the American Retirement system—private savings, pensions and employer-based retirement plans, and #SocialSecurity—has been weakened.
However, since FDR signed the program into law 85 years ago, there have been many attempts by policymakers to erode or even eliminate #SocialSecurity.

#SocialSecurity is a necessary component of many retirees’ economic security, especially those who worked in low-wage jobs during their careers. 

For most retirees, Social Security provides half of all income in retirement and keeps millions out of poverty each year. https://twitter.com/JECDems/status/1294334474642231296 QT @JECDems Today, on the 85th anniversary of the #SocialSecurity Act,  @RepDonBeyer released two reports on the weakening of the American retirement system.

We can bring those workers and communities who will be affected by our renewable energy revolution with us. We can ensure every family can thrive and help diversify local economies and find equitable job training and placement.

We must ensure healthy lives for all by cleaning up  health hazards, replacing lead pipes, and ensuring equitable access to health care, especially in communities that have endured disproportionately high COVID-19 death rates

We must insist that recovery invests in Black, Brown, and Indigenous communities to counteract racial and gender injustice;  empowers those communities to implement their projects; and prioritizes local and equitable hiring and contracting.

We can protect and restore wetlands, forests, and public lands; clean up pollution in our communities; create opportunities for family farmers and rural communities; and promote domestic manufacturing of clean tech..
We can show everyone that we value public health, education, worker protections, livable wages, and benefits for the historically underpaid, unpaid, and undervalued work.

Together, we can do the same thing to revolutionize our infrastructure, expand access to clean water, transportation, energy, and high-speed internet and retrofit millions of homes, schools, and offices to cut pollution and costs.

We must create good, safe jobs, where workers have access to unions and that they have strong organizing and bargaining rights. We must make sure that the jobs we create have strong labor standards including wages and benefits that folks can raise a family on.

I also worked closely on the Democratic Platform Drafting Committee to strongly advocate for environmental justice so that our communities come back from this and thrive.

This vision is at the core of who we are as progressives.

Addressing the economic crisis and mass unemployment is going to require major investments, and we can do it in a way that targets the legacy of racial and economic injustice AND takes on climate change.

We have an opportunity to not just recover, but to thrive.

Any attempts to undermine the postal service, particularly if for political purposes, strikes at the heart of our communities, and puts people at physical risk.

It’s unacceptable, and we need citizens’ voices heard to move the White House from this position.

In recent weeks, the new Postmaster General has terminated any overtime pay, which has caused delays. 

He’s also fired or reassigned career employees with institutional knowledge, exacerbating staffing shortages.

This goes so far beyond politics.

So, it’s distressing to see reports of mail-sorting machines being removed from postal facilities, and to hear the President state plainly that he does not support funding for the postal service because he doesn’t support mail-in voting.

In an era of distancing, the post office brings us a means of commerce, a ballot box, a critical line of communication for our rural communities and, most urgently, a way to access life-saving medication.

We’re depending on the @USPS, a cherished, founding institution in our country, to support us during a generational crisis.

It’s hard to overstate how important USPS’s swift, effective, and non-partisan service is to our communities and our country right now.
